metadata.case_name: Workmen v. Tata Locomotive Engineering Co. Ltd.

facts.text: 14 appellants were workmen in Tata Locomotive Engineering Co. Ltd., Jamshedpur, dismissed by company management based on results of domestic enquiry into charges of misconduct.
Industrial disputes between these workmen and company pending before Industrial Tribunal, Bihar.
Company filed applications under s.33 of Industrial Disputes Act for approval of dismissal action; workmen filed under s.33A complaining of action.

Company's s.33 applications held infructuous; workmen's s.33A applications considered and dismissed by Labour Court, Chotanagpur Division, Ranchi, on 2nd March 1959 in Misc. Cases Nos. 73,76,77,79-82,84-90 of 1958.
Appellants obtained special leave and preferred this appeal against Labour Court order.

On June 5, 1953, requests made on behalf of workmen to be represented by representative of Jamshedpur Mazdoor Union at enquiry; management rejected but allowed representation by co-worker from own department.

Charges against Charan Singh, Parmanand and K. Ganguli: (i) Participating in illegal strike, (ii) Leaving appointed place of duty, (iii) Inciting other employees to strike work, (iv) Threatening and intimidating other workers. Enquiry Officer found guilty of first three; no finding on fourth but found guilty of 'Behaving in a riotous and disorderly manner by shouting slogans on the shop floor'. Manager dismissed based on first three in some cases.

Charge-sheet against S.B. Nath: four acts including participating in illegal strike, leaving place, inciting, threatening. Dismissal order: guilty of 'entering the works when not on duty and inciting other employees to strike work'.

Charge-sheet against M.R. Ghosh: participation in illegal strike, inciting, leaving place, threatening/intimidating in Repair Shop. Particulars: 'By threatening and intimidating others... you took the Compressor man by his hand and got the Compressor stopped'. Dismissal included 'deliberately preventing the man in charge of the Compressor'.

Charge-sheet against Gurbux Singh: four acts. Enquiry Officer found guilty of first three and 'threatening and intimidating Mr. Charan Singh to stop work' (clerical error; actually Mr. Chakravarty). Manager agreed with findings.

Charge-sheet against S.K. Dhanda: four acts including participation, leaving place, inciting, riotous behaviour/threatening. Enquiry Officer found guilty of first three, not fourth. Manager's order noted fourth not proved but dismissed on others; formal order mistakenly included fourth.

legal_issues.text: When the management of an industry holds an enquiry into the charges against a workman for the purpose of deciding what action if any, should be taken against him, has the workman a right to be represented by a representative of his Union at the enquiry?

Whether dismissal orders were invalid because based on findings of guilt for misconduct not mentioned in the charge-sheet for certain appellants (Charan Singh, Parmanand, K. Ganguli, S.B. Nath, M.R. Ghosh, Gurbux Singh, S.K. Dhanda).

petitioner_arguments.text: Enquiry not proper/valid as workmen not allowed representation by Jamshedpur Mazdoor Union representative; fair play demands assistance for examination/cross-examination; Union rep best suited.
For Charan Singh, Parmanand, K. Ganguli: Dismissal bad as based partly on guilt of 'behaving in riotous and disorderly manner by shouting slogans' not in charge-sheet.
For S.B. Nath: Dismissal mentions guilt of 'entering works when not on duty' not accused in charge-sheet and not misconduct under standing orders.
For M.R. Ghosh: 'Deliberately preventing Compressor man' not in charge-sheet.
For Gurbux Singh: Manager wrongly considered threat to Chakravarty when Enquiry Officer said Charan Singh.
For S.K. Dhanda: Manager wrongly thought guilty of all four charges when only three proved.

court_reasoning.text: No right to Union representation at domestic enquiry; not court of law, simple facts, workman can conduct own case as in domestic tribunals; rules for govt employees have no such provision; if unfair, challengeable in industrial dispute. Employer may allow in discretion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accustomed to lawyers in courts, but domestic enquiries differ; fair intelligence suffices for questioning.

court_reasoning.text: For Charan Singh etc.: Manager would have dismissed on first three charges alone; extra finding does not vitiate as there are cases dismissed on three alone.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reason to think manager would discriminate.

court_reasoning.text: For S.B. Nath: 'Entering works when not on duty' describes manner of inciting, not separate misconduct; only inciting weighed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unnecessary/erroneous mention but not basis for punishment.

court_reasoning.text: For M.R. Ghosh: Act mentioned in particulars of fourth charge.
For Gurbux Singh: Clerical error in report (Charan Singh instead of Chakravarty); clear from body of report and evidence; no misleading; name immaterial to charge.
For S.K. Dhanda: Manager's order explicitly noted fourth not proved but dismissed on others; formal order clerical mistake.

holdings.text: Workman has no right to be represented at management enquiry by Union representative, though employer may allow in discretion.
Specific infirmities in dismissal orders do not vitiate them; clerical errors or extra findings do not affect validity where punishment based on proved charges.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Company sought approval under s.33; workmen challenged under s.33A; Labour Court disposed s.33A applications.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Labour Court's dismissal of workmenâ€™s s.33A applications upheld; no right to Union representation at domestic enquiry; specific contentions on charge-sheet infirmities rejected.

key_quotes.text: a workman against whom an enquiry is being held by the management has no right to be represented at such enquiry by a representative of his Union though of course an employer in his discretion can and may allow his employee to avail himself of such assistance.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: these are not enquiries in a court of law. It is necessary to remember also that in these enquiries, fairly simple questions of fact as to whether certain acts of misconduct were committed by a workman or not only fall to be considered
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes domestic enquiry from court proceedings.
